intro: Mentha weinerniana, commonly known as the narrow-leaf mint, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with narrow, lance-shaped leaves that have a distinct minty aroma. Its small, pale blue or purple flowers appear in whorled clusters, and it is often found in moist, shaded environments. Mentha weinerniana is valued for its culinary and medicinal uses, similar to other members of the mint family.
